This is exactly what I was thinking after an earlier comment here. If the starting point is highly unequal, there ought to be more positive effect on growth than if it's not highly unequal.

Still, the natural resources per capita ought to be looked at (forests, mines, oil and gas wells, prime farmland).

That second chart looks pretty compelling.  Indeed, if instead of stripping out all but the Eurozone, one looks only at the English-speaking advanced economies (U.S., Canada, Australia, and the U.K.---presumably New Zealand would show something similar), one sees an even steeper correlation between redistribution and growth.  Probably the extreme steepness is due somewhat to small sampling and the Cameron recessions, but the comparatively greater effect makes a lot of sense when one considers that the Anglophonic world tends to have a greater baseline of inequality (AU/NZ Ginis are actually pretty high), so you'd expect redistribution to be comparatively effective as governments started with the low-cost/high-impact projects.

Never worked in the auto industry, did you, especially in the 1990s and early 2000s. The Japanese automakers were killing the Detroit Three on everything except trucks, and GM and the other American companies were in an absolute funk trying to figure out how to build a profitable small car. The American companies were losing a lot of their best young engineers to Toyota and Honda, and the older remaining guys were just trying to keep their heads above water. I'm not saying this switch problem was a result of these troubles, yet somehow, this just sounds so 1990s. I just hope the new GM is the polar opposite of old GM, and they'd better be, because like it or not new GM is still stuck with the remnants of old GM.

The article tell us G.M. recalled this vehicle to fix the problem
What it doesn't tell is what caused the problem.
We don't know if the design was defective or in the process of putting the car together a defective part was used.
I don't see how they can build a car that has a design defective.
By now you would think everything is known on how to design a car so that if the design has a defective it can only be because the designer was not competent.
If the problem was in the parts that went into this car you have to wonder why only this car seems to have this problem.
Is it possible that other cars also have this problem and we don't know it yet.
We need to know everything about this problem so we can make sure it won't happen again in the future.

NHTSA is not involved in the detailed automotive engineering and their staff has a much harder time resolving the failure from the noisy data provided by reports. Still, the NHTSA seems to have been laggardly in responsiveness by a few years-- and NHTSA should lag GM analysis by some number of years, which hints at how large a failure occurred and how many additional bodies piled up.

First, my sympathy to all those who lost family or friends in what was marketed as an attractive starter car.

With respect to the faulty ignitions on Cobalt and similar GM cars, there seems to be a management style, especially in government agencies of **if in doubt, do nothing**.

Why do the extra work?

Why even call the letter writer to get more information on a serious problem?

Why even send a reply; just put the letter in a file (or maybe misfile it or shred it)?

For every person who complains, you can be sure that there are 10 more who did not send a letter, but had similar complaints.

Further, if the regulator's files are organized by model and year, then a reasonably astute staffer would have looked at a proper summary and the underlying records all the complaints to see if there were related issues, such as power steering failure, collisions due to car stalling, transmission problems, problems keeping a started car running. etc.

To be getting so many complaints on the Chevy Cobalt and related cars and to do nothing makes me wonder if we have the full story.

Who was/were/are the managers for the NHTSB intake on complaints? Their relation to GM (former employee[s]?)

What were the official policies and **actual practices**

"The law was used to punish Toyota for failing to report unintended accelerations; that company paid a civil penalty of $16.4 million under the act." I remember that particular penalty; I drive a Toyota. And as I recall, the Toyota engineers said that they could detect no pattern of unintended acceleration in the computer data of the cars tested. I don't recall deaths attributed to the unintended accelerations.

But how can a company get away with not issuing a recall when there are so many complaints, and so many indications of unwilling foot-dragging on the part of the company. If GM says it was"involved in claims and lawsuits," were those not disclosed to NHTSA?

It seems to me that when we constantly demonize government and underfund regulatory agencies, the result is that everyone gets a little too lax. As I recall, Ford and Firestone got into a screaming match over who was at fault before that problem was finally addressed. We need government regulation of, and active intervention in, matters of public health and safety.
